item.title: World Briefing: King Richard III to Be Reburied in Leicester, British Court Says
item.description: The court ruled that the king, who died in 1485, should be reburied in a cathedral in Leicester,​ the city​ where his remains were found in a parking lot in 2012, and not in York.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: University of Leicester/University of Leicester, via Associated Press
item.media:description: King Richard III of England, who died in 1485, was missing for 500 years. A British court ruled that he will be buried in a cathedral in Leicester.

item.title: Political Leaders in Thailand Submit to Military Takeover
item.description: Leading members of Thailand’s largest political party surrendered themselves to the military on Friday, a day after the head of the army overthrew the country’s elected government.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Thai police and army soldiers stood guard outside a military compound before former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra arrived on Friday.

item.title: Putin Indicates He’ll Respect Result of Ukrainian Election
item.description: The Russian leader gave his clearest indication yet that he would work with the winner of this weekend’s vote, but stopped short of saying the ballot would be legitimate.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Hague Court Sentences Congolese Warlord to 12 Years
item.description: Germain Katanga is only the second person to be convicted by the International Criminal Court in the decade since its work began.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:credit: Armin Taslaman/ICC, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Germain Katanga, a Congolese militia leader, at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Friday. He was sentenced to 12 years in jail for his role in the attack on a village in 2003.

item.title: Residents Try to Move On After Terrorist Attack in China
item.description: Both the majority Han Chinese and minority Uighurs in Urumqi, the regional capital of Xinjiang, say they won’t let the bloodshed come between them.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Paramilitary police on patrol in Urumqi on Friday.

item.title: W.T.O. Sides With U.S. in Dispute Over Chinese Car Tariffs
item.description: The ruling by the World Trade Organization gives the Obama administration another opportunity to portray itself as being willing to confront Beijing on trade issues.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Jeeps on display at the China Auto Show in Beijing in April.

item.title: Troops Move on Militants in Tribal Area of Pakistan
item.description: Over 1,000 Pakistani soldiers moved into a neighborhood in the North Waziristan tribal district that had become a sanctuary for Uzbek and Chinese fighters, a senior security official said.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Populist Party Gains, as Expected, in British Election
item.description: The U.K. Independence Party seemed to confirm its role as an emerging political force after early results indicated a strong showing in local elections.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Nigel Farage spoke to reporters near Biggin Hill, England, on Friday. His U.K. Independence Party has campaigned for controls on immigration and for a British exit from the European Union.

item.title: U.N. Chief Urges Aid Deliveries to Syria Without Its Consent
item.description: The request by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, in a report to the Security Council, is his strongest push to bypass Syria’s government to deliver aid.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 23
item.description: Sikhs celebrated the 535th anniversary of the birth of Guru Amardas, the third master of the Sikhs.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: U.N. Panel Says Vatican Is Lax Over Abusive Priests
item.description: The panel criticized the Roman Catholic Church, saying it failed to report sexual abuse to civil authorities or to compensate victims.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and LAURIE GOODSTEIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q & A: Gardner Bovingdon on Uighur Discontent and China’s Choices
item.description: An American professor discusses Chinese policy toward Xinjiang and possible courses the government and the people of the region may take.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Uighurs chatting in an alley near a mosque in Urumqi before proceeding to Friday Prayer.

item.title: India Ink: The Trends that Helped Sweep B.J.P. to Landslide Victory
item.description: Three key statisticians weighed in with four key trends behind the “Modi wave”: the youth vote, the Muslim vote, the anti-incumbency vote and the Uttar Pradesh state vote.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: Supporters of the Bharatiya Janata Party celebrating their victory outside the party headquarters in New Delhi, on May 16.

item.title: India Ink: In the Newly Elected Indian Parliament, Worrying Trends
item.description: Older, more criminal and less Muslim: The demographics of the new Indian Lok Sabha, or lower house of Parliament, suggest it is becoming less representative than ever.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:credit: Photo/RAVEENDRAN, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A view of the Indian parliament on May 15.

item.title: India Ink: From Cheap to Cool, Revamped Car Is Aimed at India’s Young Buyers
item.description: Tata Motors is trying to resurrect sales of the Nano with a new model that has modern features, but a higher price tag.
item.dc:creator: By SUGITA KATYAL
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A salesperson showing the new Nano Twist to a woman at a Tata Motors showroom in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on May 17.

item.title: Syrian Government Supporters Killed in Mortar Attack
item.description: An Islamist rebel group took responsibility for attacking a tent erected as part of the coming presidential election. More than 20 people died.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Urumqi Bloodshed, China Warns of Increasing Threat of Terrorism
item.description: The Chinese state news media acknowledged that the frequency of such assaults had grown and called for greater preparedness to deal with the threat of violence against civilians.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Paramilitary police officers tried to stop a photographer from taking pictures in Urumqi after an attack in a market on Thursday.

item.title: Okinawa Mayor Takes Fight Against U.S. Base to Washington
item.description: Despite reports of progress in relocating a Marine base on Okinawa, the mayor of its designated future home insists he will keep trying to block the plan.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW SIDDONS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Scholarly Response to ‘Tiger Mom’: Happiness Matters, Too
item.description: Four child psychologists say that while “Tiger Mom” parenting, popularized by Amy Chua and associated with China, gets results, it leads to “dampened” self-worth and happiness, and they warn of lower emotional functioning among children raised that way.
item.category: Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother (Book)
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A pupil at Pengying School on the outskirts of Beijing attending to her lesson.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Meena Menon, The Hindu’s Former Correspondent in Pakistan
item.description: India Ink spoke with Ms. Menon about her experience as one of two Indian correspondents in Islamabad whom Pakistan ordered to leave the country this month.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR
item.media:description: Meena Menon, former correspondent for The Hindu in Pakistan.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Billionaire Leader of ‘Mafia-Style’ Gang Sentenced to Die
item.description: A Chinese tycoon and his brother have been sentenced to death for murder and running a “mafia-style” gang that accumulated a business empire amounting to more than $6 billion.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard outside the Xianning Intermediate People's Court, in Hubei Province, where the Liu brothers and their associates were on trial.

item.title: World Briefing: Guatemala: Ex-President Sentenced
item.description: Former President Alfonso Portillo was sentenced in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Thursday to nearly six years in prison for conspiring with others to launder millions of dollars through United States bank accounts, federal prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Bombings Kill at Least 35 Pilgrims
item.description: Suicide bombers and car bombs killed at least 35 Shiite pilgrims and wounded dozens more in attacks in Baghdad on Thursday, security officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: World Briefing: Mali: Separatists Seize Towns in the North
item.description: Tuareg separatists said Thursday that they had seized control of several towns in northern Mali after routing government forces in fighting that threatens to plunge the area back into war.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing : Sanctions Imposed Against Boko Haram
item.description: The United Nations Security Council on Thursday added Boko Haram, the Nigerian extremist group, to its Al Qaeda Sanctions List, a blacklist of individuals and organizations affiliated with Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
